capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1) a) A toolkit for initial testing and a roadmap for scaling up nationwide b) Set of recommendations on redeployment of labor force in the face of the crisis 2) a) Analytical report of technical limitations, legal and organizational obstacles for full scale telecommuting and business continuity on national, oblast and local levels. b) 1,000 civil servants and several psychologists have completed courses on effective telecommuting and business continuity.

comment.narrative: There is a need to redesign of youth apprenticeship scheme and development of a toolkit for initial testing and a roadmap for scaling up nationwide. There is a need to development of practical recommendations on redeployment of labor force in the face of the crisis. There is a need to build capacity of 1,000 civil servants for effective telecommuting and business continuity

­2.1 Redesign of youth apprenticeship scheme, development of a toolkit for initial testing and a roadmap for scaling up nationwide. 2.2 Testing the toolkit by engaging 150 preselected young women and men who are temporarily jobless due to COVID-19 restrictive measures and reduced economic activities in select regions in public and private sector organizations. Scheme is to be supplemented by professional trainings introduced and implemented. Depending on the needs of particular cities or districts, apprenticeships will include seasonal works (floods), support to people most hit by the crisis (elderly, PWDs), support for social care services to address women’s additional burdens of unpaid care work with children, the sick, and elderly. 2.3 Development of practical recommendations on redeployment of labor force in the face of the crisis in addition to measures already introduced by the Government in view of a systematic approach to active employment measures for vulnerable groups. ­3.1 Review of civil service rules for home-based work, wage subsidies, sick leaves etc. in order to respond to the pandemic. Analise technical limitations, legal and organizational obstacles for full scale telecommuting and business continuity on national, oblast and local levels. Develop a package of proposals for rapid implementation. ­3.2 Building capacity of 1,000 civil servants for effective telecommuting and business continuity, including effective self-management, teamwork, maintaining social interactions with colleagues, maintaining high levels of motivation and performance. Separate trainings for managers on leading by example in crisis setting. ­3.3 Training and deployment of 5 psychologists for providing psychological help and counselling to civil servants not coping well with the crisis pressures and rapid change in working arrangements. Physical and IT infrastructure of the Public Administration Academy will be utilized as platform for delivering psycho-social counselling and advice. ­3.4 Preparing recommendations for introductions into the public administration reform process.

2.1-2.2. UNDP provided employment opportunities to 150 at-risk youth as part of its COVID-19 response program. Young people, who lost their jobs to the pandemic, took part in a subsidized three-month apprenticeship programme, accompanied by soft skills training and mentorship. The apprentices were placed in private companies, NGOs and government agencies in Nur-Sultan, Almaty and Karagandy region. They were encouraged to try out a new profession and gain experience, while receiving a ₸60,000 monthly allowance. The companies were monitoring the apprentices and hired the best performers. Of the total number of 150 programme participants, most were women, who also make up over 90 percent of the recipients of targeted social assistance in Kazakhstan. Overall, the project involved 25 mentors who were specifically trained for working with vulnerable youth. They conducted regular group and individual meetings with the apprentices. The internship also encouraged young people to pursue entrepreneurship in the future. Thanks to the new skills and knowledge acquired during the internship, about 20 percent of interns found additional funding sources for the implementation of their ideas and initiatives 2.3. Recommendation were developed as part of the SEIA. 3.1. Barriers for effective teleworking analyzed and 12 business processes selected for accelerated automation. Developed the package of specific proposals and recommendations for digitizing business processes of HR management in the public sector. 3.2. Around 2,000 civil servants were surveyed within the scope of Rapid Real Needs Assessment of Civil Servants in Crisis setting and under teleworking modalities in order to reflect the real training needs of civil servants in the current crisis. 1,006 civil servants of the central and local executive bodies of Kazakhstan, including 391 civil servants with disabilities, were trained on effective teleworking, with a specific focus on digital and communication skills. The content of the training was specifically designed for Kazakhstani civil servants following the President’s decision to switch to teleworking for 70 % of the civil servants. 3.3. UNDP CO hired a psychologist-consultant, who conducted individual psychological sessions not only to the staff of the Civil Service Agency, but their spouses and even their children. The sessions were conducted online at a convenient time for the staff by an appointment. Overall, within one month there were 3 group video conferences (sessions) and 27 individual sessions. 3.4. The Government with the UNDP CO support commenced work on the end-to-end digitalization of Kazakhstani civil service to make it “digital by default”. This implies digitizing 100 % of all the HR management related activities. As a first step, recruitment and testing are being digitized to minimize the need for the physical presence of the candidates.

description.narrative: Indicator 1: # of CSOs/CBOs using open platforms and networks to have an effective voice in subnational governance and decision-making processes.

comment.narrative: zero

1.1: 30 local government representatives and multi-stakeholder consulted including more than 40% of women 1.2: two assessment reports useful for the local governments and development partners for early recovery response targeting the most marginalized and vulnerable 1.3: Reaching out with risk communication and community engagement to more than 1 million people through two online portals, social media and IEC materials. 1.4: More than 50 people directly benefiting in at least one quarantine canton in the bordering towns of Sudurpaschim Province.

• 22 beds women isolation and holding center has been established to respond to protection issues of vulnerable women groups through multi-stakeholder approach and where 37 most vulnerable women like pregnant and disabled have been discharged. • An agro based digital platform has been established where local farmers of Dhangadhi could engage and share their agro products. This platform is expected to connect farmers and consumers even in hard times so that local supply chain is maintained and continued. This is yet to bring to formal operation. • A gender friendly quarantine center has been established to ensure women’s protection issues are addressed • Collaborated with Simraungadh municipality in Bara, to mobilize COVID-19 Prevention Group (CPG). As envisioned by the Volunteer Mobilization Guideline released by HLCC, the youth volunteer, as a part of CPG, are supporting local government to raise awareness on COVID-19 and encourage people to follow lockdown, facilitate people who came or coming from India and abroad to live in quarantine; conduct demonstrations on handwashing, coughing etiquette and other healthy behaviors etc. • Mahakali Municipality established a gender friendly quarantine spaces in Bhanu memorial school, where a separate block for women with improved gender and childcare facilities of 50 people capacity is established. Along the items supported by UNDP, the local government has provisioned a family space for those wife and husband with their children to stay together with social distancing. • An initiation with Ministry of Land Management, Agriculture and Cooperatives (MoLMAC) to develop livelihood information pack has started in Sudurpaschim Province. The pack is expected to proactively allow farmers to have easy access to information and help understand the government packages for them to uplift their economic status. • Communities at risk to COVID-19 has been mapped in Banke district to allow quick response to protection of these groups at risk to COVID-19.

description.narrative: Strengthening health systems to respond to COVID-19. UNDP is supporting Angola to strengthen the health systems in the face of COVID-19, including procuring urgently needed health and medical supplies.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

comment.narrative: Gaps on needs for COVID-19 health products and equipment in the country.

1.UNDP contributed significantly to the mapping exercise which highlighted critical funding gaps in the response. Seen as a critical technical partner in procurement, UNDP was invited by WHO to act co-administrator of WHO Angola Supply Portal for COVID-19 products. 2.With UNDP’s assistance, Angola’s CCM was able to mobilise 3.3 million USD from the Global Fund’s CR19 RM mechanism. Of this amount, 2.85 million USD will be managed by UNDP for the procurement of COVID-19 diagnostic tests, PPE for health professionals and community health workers. 3.UNDP was instrumental in helping the Ministry of Health issue its first Quantification Report for the COVID-19 response and in informing its review. The Report was well received by the World Bank which used it as the basis for the procurement of 15 million USD worth of COVID-19 health products and equipment; 4.The Luanda Provincial Government Strategy for Community Engagement in COVID-19 was finalized with technical assistance from UNDP. Also, an MoU was signed or the disbursement of 36,893USD allocated to the hiring and training of a cadre of 113 Community Volunteers. Another 25,000 USD were disbursed to ANASO which helped reach 14 584 families in Luanda’s municipalities with IEC materials on COVID-19. Food baskets were delivered to 2,125 families, including 850 adults and 350 Children living with or affected by HIV. UNDP has partnered with WHO and the Provincial Government of Luanda to promote hygiene and sanitation conditions in informal markets.

description.narrative: Socio-economic impact assessment of and recovery from COVID-19 and to find ways to mitigate them with sustainable, resilient and rights-based solutions crafted with the public and private sectors.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

comment.narrative: No socio-economic assessment for COVID-19.

1.Over 336.500 people reached by Emission of three radio programs per week in Otchivambo and Nhaneca-Humbe on climate change adaptation and disaster resilience through Radio Cunene, covering COVID aspects; 2.UNDP has technically led and conducted three socioeconomic assessments of the potential impacts of COVID-19 in Angola, including an additional assessment in partnership with UNCT and World Bank that contributed to elaborate the UN Socio-Economic Response and Recovery Plan. 3.Two MoUs signed with the Ministry of High Education and Innovation and Provincial Government to conduct the mapping of national entrepreneurship and innovation ecosystem in Angola. 4.Provided legal aid to over 600 women survivors of domestic violence. 5.UNDP provided support to provincial coordination, communication with Huila, Namibe and Cunene Covid-19 contingency plan was produced and established partnership with provincial vice-governors leading the DRM and Provincial Civil Protection Commissions. Governments, UNDP and EU developed the COVID-19 Monitor using Power BI and GIS Map.

1.Conduct a socio-economic impact assessment of COVID-19 pandemic on informal workers and informal economic units in urban areas 2.Provide technical advisory services to the Government for an assessment of social protection needs and extension of social protection to informal workers with priority to women and youth in urban areas 3.Support women, youth and members of key and vulnerable populations - with informal employment to register their businesses. 4.Strengthen business skills (business plan, seed capital management, accounting, marketing and e-marketing, finance and procurement, inventory control, soft skills and peer-learning among the female participants) of 300 women and young girls with informal employment, including at least 15 persons with disabilities and people living with HIV, through the attendance of vocational training courses 5.support the design and production of a distance learning distance learning package of vocational training, identified in dialogue with business associations, including procurement of the equipment needed 6.In partnership with INEFOP, Civil Society Organizations and business associations, support 400 women, young informal workers and members of key and vulnerable populations, who completed a vocational training course, to join an apprenticeship program in private and public companies and receive professional kits and tutoring 7.Mobilize private companies to expand their business opportunities through micro-franchising business models 8.Provide electronic equipment and conduct training on digital technologies (spreadsheet, emails, use of applications to run a digital business, digital marketing, e-commerce, data privacy, data protection and digital safety) to representatives of business associations of informal workers or informal economic units

description.narrative: Inclusive and Multi-Sectoral Crisis Management and Response to COVID-19.UNDP is helping Angola advances inclusive and integrated crisis management by supporting government to maintain core functions.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

comment.narrative: Gaps on institutional capacity in business continuity, uphold rule of law and human rights, address exacerbated gender inequalities.

1.UNDP supported the Parliament in the design of legislation for remote working sessions. 2.300 law enforcement agents strengthened capacities on the police daily police duties, including detention, investigation, police protection and accountability on COVID-19 crisis. 3.UNDP supported safe functioning of local markets to avoid closures, to ensure low income families maintain their livelihoods and to advance fundamental human rights.

capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1. # and type of partnership are operational to contribute into strengthening capacity for inclusive and multi-sectoral response 2. Percentage of women organisation, gender, PWD and other vulnerable group stakeholders involved in multi-stakeholder platform 3. Comprehensive gender-sensitive information and communication produced and delivered to target groups to prevent and reduce stigma in relevant to those who associate with the outbreak corona virus diseases 2019 and gender equality at the context of crisis situation. (disaggregated by sex) 4. # of integrated rights-based, equity and gender-responsive policy solutions (including food security and nutrition) creating an enabling environment for pandemic response that have been implemented

comment.narrative: 1. Unavailability multi-stakeholder platform and partnership programme to enable inclusive multi-sectoral response at sub-national level. 2. Limited participation of women’s organizations, disable people organizations' and vulnerable groups in multi stakeholder platform to response COVID-1, in the context of patriarchal culture. 3. The spread of misinformation and communication delivered to target groups that risk perpetuating stigma and gender discrimination, in the situation of crisis. 4. Lack of an integrated rights-based, equity and gender-responsive policy solutions to ensure effectiveness od social protection response

1. Inclusive and multi-sectoral coordination and public-private partnership platform established and operational at 5 (five) subnational level 2. Strengthened capacity of multi-sectoral platform and sub national governments on the gender-responsive policy advocacy and development at crisis situation 3. Raised awareness of # people to prevent and reduce stigma in relevant to those who associate with the outbreak corona virus diseases 2019 and gender equality at the context of crisis situation. (disaggregated by sex) 4. 1 responsive policy solutions developed

UNDP has successfully increased the co-ordination of capacity-mapping and provided technical support to 7 sub-national governments.It includes the the multi-stakeholders engagement to support inclusive response of COVID19, and to ensure protection to vulnerable group such as GBV victims/survivors,etc.
The needs assessment specific to pandemics has provided baseline support to recovery and contingency planning processes in 7 provinces. GBV case handling SOPs during pandemic at pilot police offices, local hospitals and the women and child protection units at the national and sub-national levels, were established (some are legalized and some are under finalization) to ensure reporting and referral channels are resilient and keep open in the middle of crisis. 10 workshops and training programmes with OPDs were conducted and have raised awareness and capacity of technical government agencies, OPDs, and community & family care services in preventing and handling COVID-19 cases for PwDs.
Communication strategy was implemented to reach massive audience, by conducting virtual seminars, communication campaign in public transportation such as MRT and LRT, Transjakarta and social media to blast the message of dangerous COVID 19 and readiness of governance to support protection of vulnerable groups during pandemic.

comment.narrative: 1. No comprehensive study available yet on socio economic impacts of COVID-19 pandemic in Indonesia 2. No report and measurement on social implication of COVID-19 pandemic for gender in Indonesia 3. Limited number of social protection facilitator and knowledge on different schemes of social protection in COVID-19 crisis 4. Adhoc and silo coordination mechanism on social protection delivery in country

1. Two reports focusing at impact of COVID-19 on socioeconomic sectors and household, including recommendations on workable solutions for immediate, medium to longer term, 2. One report focusing on measures to mitigate and/or reduce gender-based violence and unpaid work of women. 3. 250 social welfare workers/village cadre skills in social protection increased 4. At least 1 SOP on inter-agency coordination for social protection developed at National and/or Sub-National levels

To understand the socio-economic impact of the pandemic, there were studies undertaken to measure impacts of 20,000 households, 1,100 MSMEs and 1,000 individuals. It includes measure of the welfare and livelihood of women ( in the perspectives of escalation of GBV and unpaid care work) during pandemic .

description.narrative: Authorities are supported to provide inclusive and multi-sectoral crisis management and response to COVID-19, in coordination with the UN Country Team and in direct collaboration with the World Health Organisation in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 1. Indicator: Extent to which authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina manage to respond to the emergency needs related to COVID-19 disease outbreak in a timely and coordinated manner.

comment.narrative: 1. Effective

1.UNDP is supporting overall coordination of the crisis by supporting the Civil Protection and Rescue Coordination Body to coordinate actions and exchange information among relevant stakeholders, as well as deploy tools that help the whole-of-system data collection and management, as well as information sharing on the crisis to the public. UNDP is also conducting an extensive, in-depth analysis focusing on the COVID-19 response and challenges from the security point of view. The assessment provides an overview of the human security and policing sectors in country, national and regional challenges and vulnerabilities as well as general analysis of the security threats and proposals for prospective interventions in this field. The analysis have mapped several priorities and provided recommendations for policy and operational support to the authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
1. Effective

description.narrative: The socio-economic impact of COVID-19 is addressed through a whole-of-society approach and rapid economic impact assessment available and launch of a real-time economic “pulse” meter platform;
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 1. Number of measures developed based on the assessment findings and companies supported to recover from the COVID-19 crisis.

comment.narrative: 1. No
1. At least 3 assessments and/or tools produced or supported with recommendations which proivde basis to at least 5 projects in implementing Covid-19 recovery measures

1. 7 assessments/tools 8 projects On behalf of the UNCT and in direct cooperation with the World Health Organisation, UNDP provided support to the authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina to ensure effective and multi-sectoral crisis coordination in the country. It included information management on the current situation and needs for the COVID-19 pandemic in the country, including response, recovery and prevention planning, as well as resource mobilization. Also, in May 2020 UNDP prepared an Economic Impact Assessment of COVID-19 in BiH, a survey that served to assess the extent of the immediate COVID-19 impact to businesses and industries in the country. The Economic Pulse of Bosnia and Herzegovina is an interactive platform for collecting data on the socio-economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including the state of the private sector and it was launched by UNDP as part of this project. In addition, serological tests were purchased for medical institutions in Bosnia and Herzegovina on their request for immediate assistance, due to the increasing number of registered cases.
1. At least 3 assessments and/or tools produced or supported with recommendations which proivde basis to at least 5 projects in implementing Covid-19 recovery measures

Ind.1
▪ Une proposition de revue du cadre institutionnel et réglementaire de la gestion de risque de catastrophes et crise intégrant le retour d’expérience COVID19 ▪ Deux directions régionales de la santé ainsi que deux commissions régionales de gestion de catastrophes et crises et un comité local institutionnel des zones d’intervention du projet bénéficieront d’un appui en renforcement de capacité en coordination de la crise ; ▪ Dix associations bénéficieront de financements (grants) pour mettre en œuvre des initiatives qui visent à renforcer la résilience de la société face aux conséquences de la pandémie sur l’exacerbation des conflits communautaires et environnementaux et réduire son impact sur la cohésion sociale et la marginalisation des femmes et des catégories les plus vulnérables. ▪ Quatre municipalités bénéficieront d’un appui en renforcement de capacité en préparation à et coordination de la crise.
Ind.2. ▪ 4 initiatives incubées proposées par les jeunes femmes et hommes des localisations visées ▪ Une plateforme e-learning pour l’éducation à la santé et environnement est mise en place en partenariat avec l’Université Virtuelle de Tunis ▪ 200 professionnel.les de santé formé.es via la plateforme e-learning ▪ 10 000 citoyen.nes sensibilisé.es atteint.es à travers cette plateforme

description.narrative: Indicator 1. Whether COVID response and recovery strategy development is supported Indicator 2. Whether resource mobilization and financing strategy in place and funds toward recovery available and utilized by 30 September 2020 Indicator 3. Whether COVID-19 socio-economic assessment tool by using BIG data is developed

comment.narrative: no covid situation, therefore no need to have a rapid response to build back.

Target 1. National strategy developed by 1 June 2020 Target 2. Resource mobilization and financing strategy in place and funds toward recovery available and utilized by 30 September 2020. Target 3. COVID-19 socio-economic assessment tool by using BIG data developed.

Results of target 1: • UNDP was the technical lead on the socio-economic recovery and assisted the Deputy Prime Minister’s (DPM) Office in developing a recovery strategy though an inclusive process. Based on consultations four strategic areas, social recovery, economic recovery, supportive governance and institutions, and environmental and climate resilience are identified as crucial for recovery within the coming 2 years to build forward better. The Socio-Economic Response Plan was developed by the country office to contribute to the Government’s action plan and its implementation plan for pandemic response.
Results of target 2: • Resource mobilization and financing strategy was integrated in implementation plan of the Government Integration plan approved in December, 2020. • The UNDP’s transformational learning journey, “What development means in a post normal Mongolia” is being developed.
Results of target 3: • With the National Statistics Office and Customs and Tax Information Center, the pilot estimation of the household consumption, inequality and other indicators by using VAT is being undertaken. By January, the report will be ready.

description.narrative: The Project adapts COVID-19 responses for specific population via 1 public advocacy/behavioral insights & aggregated location data; & 2 multidimensional needs mapping for tailored assistance for vulnerable communities & support to private sector (SMEs)
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 1.1: Recruitment of national UNVs 1.2. Application of behavioral insights (BI) and tailored communication campaign in multi-languages (Arabic, English, Hindi, Urdu and others) 1.3. Support a mobile platform to support real-time identification of multidimensional needs arising from vulnerable communities, i.e. Jleeb Al-Shoyokh and Mahboula areas, as well as people with disabilities 1.4. Pilot a digital platform to trace (past movements) of COVID-19 patients with rights-based approach 1.5: Strengthening a hotline (support system) for supporting victims of domestic violence 2.1. Running Hackathons for New Business Prototypes (knowledge-based/innovation track and e-commerce track) 2.2. Identification of business mentors and mentorship programs drawn from the national as well as global pool of business leaders (start-ups)

comment.narrative: All indicators were set at 0.

1.1: Recruitment of national UNVs 1.2. Application of behavioral insights (BI) and tailored communication campaign in multi-languages (Arabic, English, Hindi, Urdu and others) = to be concluded in 1.3. Support a mobile platform to support real-time identification of multidimensional needs arising from vulnerable communities, i.e. Jleeb Al-Shoyokh and Mahboula areas, as well as people with disabilities 1.4. Pilot a digital platform to trace (past movements) of COVID-19 patients with rights-based approach 1.5: Strengthening a hotline (support system) for supporting victims of domestic violence 2.1. Running Hackathons for New Business Prototypes (knowledge-based/innovation track and e-commerce track) 2.2. Identification of business mentors and mentorship programs drawn from the national as well as global pool of business leaders (start-ups)

1.1: Recruitment of national UNVs 2.1. Two innovation challenges (Local Hackathon and Regional ideathon) were organise to solicit creative ideas to help overcoming covid-19 related challenges. 2.2. Identification of business mentors and mentorship programs drawn from the national as well as global pool of business leaders (start-ups).
Extra activities added at a later stage: - Volunteers manuals were developed and in the process to be printed and circulated widely in Kuwait, and Training Of Trainers For Volunteers And Volunteer Management has been delivered. - Rapid Response Catalogue were developed and printed and circulated widely in Kuwait. - Development of a policy paper, titled: “Polarized Reactions, Attitudes and Behaviors towards Covid-19: Behavioral Analysis”. - Socio-Economic Analysis on the effect of COVID-19: UNDP Kuwait is leading a socioeconomic assessment on the impact of COVID19 on the most vulnerable groups such as people with disabilities (PWD) and migrants. Collaborating with the Public Authority of The Disabled (PADA), UNDP Kuwait aims to provide a review and analysis on current social protection processes put in place for PWD. - SDG Accelerator lab for SMEs in Kuwait is under development, to be concluded in Q1 2021. - Development of Chatbot powered by Artificial Intelligence (AI) to improve the wellbeing of people during the crisis. Results from mental and physical health questionnaires will assist in the design of an interactive platform. The interactive WhatsApp platform is aimed at Kuwaiti citizens and residents towards accessing information related to their health on a real-time basis, to be concluded in Q1 2021.

description.narrative: Strengthening the capacity of national health systems to respond to COVID-19, including through procurement of critical medical equipment and enhancing the effectiveness of risk communication
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 1.1 Improved Capacity of National Health System to conduct domestic testing of COVID19 Cases 1.2 Number of COVID19 Cases identified and contained through immediate testing and response services 1.3 Number of Multimedia Awareness Campaigns on COVID19 Preparedness and Response disseminated and distributed at the National scale 1.4 Number of people particularly the Vulnerable groups disaggregated by gender that are supported through Community Outreach and Engagement support initiatives.

comment.narrative: 1.1 Complete procurement and delivery of PCR Testing Equipment with relevant consumables and supplies 1.2 At least 500 COVID19 Tests administered and completed locally with timely avaiable results 1.3 At least 100 Multimedia Awareness Messages on COVID19 Preparedness and Response produced and nationally disseminated 1.4 At least 300 vulnerable families supported through COVDI19 Community Outreach support

1. Under the COVID-19 Response project, UNDP in partnership with UNICEF successfully procured a RT-qPCR machine and 2,000 test kits to enhance local testing capabilities. 2. Under the reprogrammed CERF funds, UNDP also procured 2,000 Cepheid test kits for Samoa's existing GenXpert machines (previously funded under GFATM projects). 3. In addition to that, UNDP worked through a number of civil society organizations and directly with small businesses who were heavily impacted by COVID to locally produce face masks in Samoa, Niue and Tokelau, and hand sanitizer in Samoa, for distribution to health care workers and vulnerable households.

description.narrative: Support to a inclusive and integrated COVID-19 response that leaves no one behind
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 2.1 Number for Zoom License successfully procured and activated to support Governments' Business Continuity plan 2.2 Number of PPEs that were locally produced in accordance with WHO Guidance and disseminated nationally 2.3 Number of people particularly the vulnerable groups disaggregated by gender and age supported with social protection support of food packages and hygiene kits 2.4 Number of Persons with disabilities disaggregated by gender and age supported with social protection support of food packages and hygience kits.

comment.narrative: 2.1 At least 50 Zoom licenses successfully procured and activated to support Governments' Business Continuity plan 2.2 At least 300 2 plies facemasks locally producted and distributed at national scale for infection prevention and control 2.3 At least 500 vulnerable families supported through social protection immediate support of food packages and hygiene kits 2.4 At least 300 persons' with disabilities supported through social protection immediate support of food packages and hygiene kits.

1. UNDP successfully procured 78 Zoom licenses to support the Governments' of Samoa, Niue and Tokelau business continuity. 2. In UNDP's partnership with the Samoa Victim Support Group on local production of face masks, 15 women survivors of DV/GBV were selected to contribute to the effort and sew cloth face masks from the confines of their homes given the COVID restrictions. This group of women alone have sewn over 1,500 masks, becoming the main income earners for their families during these trying times. The masks are also sold online via the Maua App, and have been purchased by private companies, private citizens, and Poutasi village (a COVID-19 quarantine site for those returning from NZ). Furthermore, a field visit to the project on 16 September revealed that SVSG's extensive sharing of posts promoting the UNDP face mask production on social media attracted the attention of a new hotel in Apia, which placed the order for sewing of all its tablecloths and napkins by the women survivors of violence. 3. Progress-on-track for distribution of hygiene packages, food voucher and cash power/electricity support to vulnerable families, in partnership with MWCSD. 4. UNDP in partnership with NOLA successfully distributed 450 hygiene packages as support to Persons with Disabilities in Samoa. 5. Progress-on-track for support to Koko Youth Farmers on plant care, soil and weather management training, in partnership with Chamber of Commerce, SPREP and Samoa MET.

description.narrative: COVID-19 SocEc Imp Ass & Recov_Supporting Socio-Economic Impact Assessments and COVID-19 Recovery
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 3.1 Timely completion of Socio-Economic Impact Assessment of COVD19 Impacts on Samoa 3.2 Timely completion of Rapid Assessment of Vulnerabilities in Rarotonga and Autitaki Cook Islands due to the COVID19

comment.narrative: 3.1 Completed SEIA of COVID19 Impacts on Samoa that is fully costed 3.2 Completed Rapid Assessment of Vulnerabilities in Rarotonga and Aitutaki Cook Islands due to COVID19 3.3 Completed SEIA of COVID19 Impacts on Tokelau that is fully costed

The initial SEIA for Samoa has been completed, but primary household-level data collection is still underway and on track.
In May, UNDP partnered with the Cook Islands Ministry of Internal Affairs and ADB to support the Rapid Assessment for COVID-19 related vulnerability and perceptions on Rarotonga and Aituitaki. Findings from this assessment highlighted the impact of COVID on household welfare and employment, and provided insights to assist in the development of the Government's socio-economic response.
The Pa Enua Rapid assessment on the welfare of vulnerable people is pending.
